title: Riot's true burden of knowledge
body:
You hear this time to time that the reason for timers was because there was a burden of knowledge. That players, newer players to be specific, has no idea when they spawn or anything. Now adding the timers for all the buffs is pretty understandable.

However the true burden of knowledge and perhaps the biggest that for some reason has been glossed over for years, are ratios. In order to know the champion's scaling ratios, you would have to go to a website such as lolwiki as it is not given during champion preview in the store page or even ingame. There is no way newer players to know about a champ's ratios without googling it.

Now I think knowing about ratios is hugely important, more so than anything else imo. As knowing about ratios you can have a a lot better understanding of the champion and knowing what kind of items or runes to run with. 

So why must players use an outside source to have a better and clearer understanding of a champion?

They wouldn't just have the reports sent to them, they would process them certain way.

That's why programming is so connected to mathemathics - because basic math is about logic, thinking and phenomena relations, not "numbers".

So yes, If they cared and would take the risk, they would pay someone who is actual proffesional and educated programmer to sit down for more than 1 minute and instead of excuses would design actual algorithm considering as much things that would help the system as possible. Plus on systems like these usually work set of people that can brainstorm solutions faster.

At my college, they don't teach us "So you are supposed to decide this statement? Do they expect you to check it for every value?", instead they teach us "Think of a way how to simplify it, there is, you know, like five different approaches for deciding statements, decide which one is more efficient, make it general, then proceed with specifying it."

I don't expect Riot to do it, but your argument is simply invalid nearly everytime it is used.

The info is available to those who know where to look (Surrender@20 can provide a lot of the stats for new champs), it's just that it's not easily accessible and you would likely have to look at multiple sites in order to find everything.

This is not so much a burden of knowledge, but a barrier to access that knowledge.

I always found it weird that the league client was so useless at providing specific information for champs.

Maybe its for the same reason not releasing a sandbox mode for fear of "raising the bar."

I wish I was joking about that.

Fighting games pretty much require time being spent in training mode to practice certain moves and combos.

Fighting games are extremely hard to get into because you will get your ass beat all the time.

Some people don't like getting their ass beat all the time.

This way, people are on a more even playing field v those who would have the time to hone their skills in a sandbox mode.

All the time in training mode in the world isn't going to help me predict or read the opponent. That's experience. Experience is the greatest equalizer in these kinds of games, not mechanical prowess, which is what training mode is primarily going to enforce.

in fighting games, you won't get any sort of "combo" knowledge by doing it on enemies.
You have to train it first. And some combos are really complex. I remember spending 2 weeks in training mode, like 2 hours per day doing the same shit over and over and over again. Until I managed to do it with a 50% success rate.
That was like 2-15 seconds (depending where I screw up) of practicing a combo, feel the timing, etc. That's about 4 times per minute for 2 hours.

Compare this to LoL for example, most skills have cooldowns. Especially combos that use longer one (such as ultimates). Instead of like practice, and as soon as I mess up, prepare to practice again. Here you got to wait for cooldowns over and over again. Making the "practice" much more slow and seemly pointless.

And that's why you think "experience vs the world" is better than actual training. When in fact, for what is considered "Basics". You need to spend A LONG TIME training. Before that "experience vs the world" and "predict the opponent" comes to play, you must understand the basics of what you are playing. And again, for basics, you need training.

Hence why, fighting games require a lot of training. Sure, experience is a good thing. After you learned how to use your combo. Learn at least 2-3 rotations of it so that you won't end up being predictable. But depending on difficulty, that can take a long time.

This is what I was playing in for like 1 year

I dont know why everybody is comparing a sandbox mode of a moba game to a fighting game when both are entirely different from each other. Thats like comparing street fighter to final fantasy. 

With sandbox mode, you can create scenarios and practice going against these said scenarios. You can test builds without painstakingly waiting. You can also practice certain skills and especially skills that goes over walls so you can have a clearer and better understanding. Can this skill go through this wall? Is there a certain angle I have to approach this? How big is the actual hitbox? Ect. From a solo que perspective, you would have the tools to better grasp the ingame environment. 

But thats just soloQ though. What about ranked teams? Professional play? Dont you think this mode would be of great benefit to them? As said before, creating and simulating scenarios on the fly? Practicing and coming up with new team comps against other comps.

There is so much sandbox mode can offer that I literally have no idea why anybody would be against this. The only reason I heard of them not doing this is for fear of raising the bar which is absolute bollocks.

Well first of all yes. There have been tons of posts discussing the fact we still have to go online to a website to look up all champion information. It's got almost nothing to do with technical challenges and has everything to do with Riot not wanting to have to update information in two different places. 

Its repeating work. They have to go in and update the game to reflect the new changes as well as the website. Changing some text on a website is probably one of the easiest things you can do coding wise. Changing it in game requires the change to be made to the code (again not hard once it is set up) but someone has to change it, then confirm it is correct and then slate it for the next push. The champion data is not perfectly accurate and it never will be. Its far easier for them to change this stuff online in one simple place that is accessible to everyone and does not repeat work.

You are missing the point. Would you want to play Mass Effect, Skyrim, or a similar storyline based game if you had to go to the company website in order to access the background info and lore? Of Course not. A similar principle applies here, where players can't get a solid idea of whether a champ is meant to scale with levels, AP, AD, etc. more without going to the company website. Of course it is hard work, but that doesn't mean that it shouldn't be done.

Imagine going into a game and building full AP on Zyra. Yeah it wouldn't be horrible, but her low scaling makes mpen MUCH better on her.

That said, no reason for them to update the current client if they fully intend to incorporate this information in the new one.
